Award.AwardTitle: Eyes on the future: optimizing science output for next generation surveys with joint crowdsourced and automated classification techniques
Award.AbstractNarration:
Future galaxy surveys will produce so much data that astronomers will no longer be able to rely on their previous methods of classifying them in order to extract the science of galaxy formation and evolution through cosmic history. Although "crowd-sourced" galaxy classifications tap into a vast resource of volunteer labor, even major efforts like the Galaxy Zoo (GZ) will not be able to keep up. This project will build on the GZ database, extending methods to other epochs in the Universe, and simultaneously use the results of the citizen science work together with machine learning to develop new automated classification tools. Using the proven research value of involving the public and the broader community, and with a new generation of intelligent computer methods, this study will build on the best of both.

While crowd-sourced galaxy classifications have proven their worth on a decade of data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), there remain two major challenges to making them a standard component of the data processing pipelines for the next generation of surveys. The first is proving the utility of the method at high redshifts, where more galaxies have irregular or clumpy morphologies. The second acknowledges that even crowdsourcing does not have the capacity for the data volume and rates that are to come, requiring new more sophisticated machine classification algorithms. This project will develop catalogs for high-redshift crowd-sourced data and for simulated galaxies, and develop a new automated classification tool that extends to higher redshifts with a training pipeline adaptable to multiple galaxy surveys. It includes three science projects: (a) directly constrain galaxy size and mass growth rates; (b) measure any relationship between bar-dominated disks and fueling of active galactic nuclei, and (c) quantify the demographics and evolution of disk sub-structures. Efforts to automate morphological classifications using parametric and non-parametric techniques have been reasonably successful for SDSS, but did not extend to deriving the necessary detailed structural parameters. The GZ crowd-sourcing project has been successful beyond expectations, providing scientifically viable parameters from volunteer work and leading to over a hundred peer-reviewed papers. This study will extend both of these approaches in preparation for much larger future surveys, which expect to produce as much data per night as ten years of SDSS.

The high-level catalogs to be produced, and the new classification algorithms to be used, are to be released publically, and will be a valuable resource for the community. Along with informal guided-inquiry projects, GZ will be implemented into undergraduate astronomy courses. Students involved in this work will get well-defined PhD projects and acquire technical skills valuable in their future professional careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The size of astronomical data sets is increasing at a tremendous rate with the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope expected to produce 40 Terabytes of data per night. Previous sky surveys have successfully used citizen science techniques to accelerate the process of galaxy morphology classification, namely the Galaxy Zoo project incorporating effort from hundreds of thousands of volunteer labelers. However, new techniques must be developed that combine both human and machine classifiers to extract the most information possible from these new surveys and produce catalogs that are useful across a wide range of research in astronomy, including topics related to galaxy morphology and evolution.  Hence the intellectual merit of the Eyes on the Future project was to carry out research to optimize science output for next generation surveys with joint crowdsourced and automated classification techniques.

Led by the University of Minnesota, and including collaborators from the Universities of Oxford, Portsmouth and Harvard, the goals of the project were four-fold: (1) the development and publication of catalogs based on the Zooniverse citizen science projects within the Galaxy Zoo framework: Hubble (GZH), CANDELS, Illustris and UKIDSS; (2) the development, implementation and analysis of the Galaxy Zoo: Illustris project which classified galaxies produced by state-of-the-art numerical simulations; (3) the development, implementation and analysis of Galaxy Zoo: Express, the simulation of a process to combine human and machine classifications in near-real time; and (4) science exploitation of the above projects.

Catalogs accompanied by peer-reviewed journal publications were produced for the Galaxy Zoo: Hubble, CANDELS and Illustris projects, requiring new methods to be developed for example to debias the data against redshift. Collectively these papers have received 29 citations in the past two years demonstrating their importance to the broader astronomical community. Scientific results by the team based on the development of the catalogs include papers published showing (a) that there is a small, yet statistically significant, correlation between barred galaxies and those with active galactic nuclei suggesting that bars do play a role in the fueling of an active black hole; (b) that spiral structure, measured through the GZ data and including parameters such as pitch angle and arm number, has no effect on the relationship between star formation rate and mass; (c) that comparing the implied morphological characteristics for the Illustris dataset with those that are observed in the real Universe exhibit an apparent overabundance of simulated galaxies for which volunteers discern discrete features in the galaxy image. The development of the catalogs and concomitant science provided further insight into how the citizen science method can be used in upcoming surveys.

In addition, significant effort was put into the development of the Galaxy Zoo: Express project, resulting in a 2018 publication showing that a factor 8 efficiency gain can be made over simple volunteer classification work by incorporating near real-time training for machine learning with volunteer-produced classifications accelerated by selecting for highly skilled labels. This result holds real promise for delivering on the speed-up required to process the large amounts of data coming off of the new surveys.

The work supported by this grant on catalogs and science derived from them resulted in sixteen peer-reviewed publications. The impact of these papers is significant with over 335 citations collectively made already.

The broader impacts of the Eyes on the Future project relate to the hundreds of thousands of members of the general public engaged in the Galaxy Zoo projects. Apart from their contributions to classifying galaxies, these volunteers are exposed to the science of galaxy evolution through social media and on the discussion boards related to Galaxy Zoo. Fortson and Scarlata participated in the development of an exhibit at the Bell Museum related to the research work in this project.  In formal education activities, team members worked with Astronomy instructors to integrate GZ material into introductory laboratories and lectures.  Additionally, Fortson created and taught an honors seminar course on Crowdsourcing, drawing substantially on GZ and Zooniverse material. We supervised five undergraduate students and a highschool student. We trained three postdocs, and three graduate students; two graduate students obtained their theses on work related to this grant. Two postdocs and one graduate student now have careers in data science. One graduate student now teaches physics and astronomy at an undergraduate college.
